hadiths.english_translation: Fragment entry - Incomplete hadith text. Only companion name mentioned: Aswad ibn Asram al-Muharibi (May Allah be pleased with him)

potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only a companion name without complete chain of transmission or full hadith text. It appears to be a section header or fragment from the source text rather than a complete hadith record.

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Aswad ibn Asram al-Muharibi (May Allah be pleased with him): I said 'O Messenger of Allah, advise me.' He said 'Control your hand.' I said 'What do I control if I cannot control my hand?' He said 'Control your tongue.' I said 'What do I control if I cannot control my tongue?' He said 'Do not extend your hand except toward good, and do not speak with your tongue except with what is known'

narrators.name: Abdur-Rahman Abu Said Duhayim
narrators.full_name: Abdur-Rahman ibn Abdillah ibn al-Walid al-Khatib al-Dimashqi

narrators.name: Amru ibn Abi Salamah
narrators.alternative_names: Amru ibn Abi Salamah al-Basr, Amru ibn Sulayman

narrators.name: Ubaidullah ibn Ali
narrators.full_name: Ubaidullah ibn Ali ibn Abdullah al-Akhbar

narrators.name: Aswad ibn Asram al-Muharibi
narrators.full_name: Aswad ibn Asram ibn al-Aswad al-Muharibi
narrators.alternative_names: Aswad al-Muharibi, Companion from Muharib tribe

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Multiple consecutive 'an (عَنْ) narrations without explicitly establishing direct hearing between narrators
Sadaqah ibn Abdullah, Ubaidullah ibn Ali, and Sulayman ibn Habib all use 'an (عَنْ) which introduces ambiguity in the transmission
Ubaidullah ibn Ali's theological position (associated with Murji'ah) requires careful evaluation, though he was not known for severe issues in hadith transmission

potential_issues.impact: Sadaqah ibn Abdullah, Ubaidullah ibn Ali, and Sulayman ibn Habib all narrate using 'an (عَنْ) instead of direct terms like حَدَّثَنَا or سَمِعْتُ. While none of these narrators are known mudallis (hidden reporters), the lack of explicit direct transmission terms does introduce a level of ambiguity, though this is mitigated by their overall reliability.

Ubaidullah ibn Ali was associated with Murji'ah theological position. However, he is not severely criticized in hadith transmission and his reliability is acceptable (La Ba'sa Bihi grade). His theological position does not significantly impact the hadith's authenticity.

Topics: Advice from Prophet ﷺ on controlling the hands and tongue
Incident of Aswad ibn Asram seeking counsel from the Prophet ﷺ
Dialogue on moral conduct and restraint
Prohibition of harm through hands and speech

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Kharshah (May Allah be pleased with him): I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ saying: 'There will be a trial (fitnah) after me. The one sleeping during it is better than the one awake, and the one awake is better than the one standing, and the one standing is better than the one running. So whoever encounters it, let him go with his sword to the stone, strike it and break it, then lie down until it ends.'

chainIssues: Thabit ibn Ajlan and Abu Kathir both use 'an (عَنْ) in this chain
This chain has more indirect transmission terms compared to the first chain

potential_issues.issue: Multiple chains with variation in transmission terms
potential_issues.impact: The three chains show variation in transmission methodology. The first chain uses سَمِعْتُ (explicit hearing) from the companion, while the second and third chains use عَنْ or قَالَ, creating some ambiguity. However, all narrators are reliable (Saduq or better), and the companion Kharshah is Thiqah.
Suwayd ibn Abdul-Aziz is graded as 'Saduq Yugrib' (produces some strange/weak narrations), which is lower than purely 'Saduq'. This affects the reliability of the first chain containing him.

Topics: Description of trials and tribulations (fitnah) that will occur after the Prophet ﷺ
Advice on behavior during times of trials
Incident of Kharshah reporting about the Hour and civil discord

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Tariq al-Muharibi: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'When one of you spits, let him not spit to the right, nor to the left, but beneath his feet'

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Fudayl

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Multiple consecutive عَنْ narrations without explicit direct transmission terms
Sufyan al-Thawri, Mansur, and Rabi'i ibn Hirash all use عَنْ in this chain

potential_issues.impact: While all narrators in this chain are thiqah (reliable), the use of عَنْ by Sufyan al-Thawri, Mansur, and Rabi'i ibn Hirash introduces some ambiguity about direct transmission. However, these are all well-known reliable narrators without issues of tadlis, so the impact is minimal.

Topics: Advice on proper etiquette for spitting
Incident of companion receiving instruction from Prophet ﷺ on cleanliness

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Tariq ibn Abdullah: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said to him: 'O Tariq, prepare for death before death comes'

chainIssues: Abdah ibn Abdullah opens with قَالَ instead of حَدَّثَنَا, which may indicate indirect transmission
Qais ibn al-Rabi' is graded as Saduq Yukhti' (prone to errors)
Mansur and Rabi'i use عَنْ in this chain

potential_issues.issue: Qais ibn al-Rabi' graded as Saduq Yukhti'
potential_issues.impact: This narrator is known to make errors in his narrations. Combined with عَنْ transmissions from other narrators, this introduces some reliability concerns.

potential_issues.issue: Use of قَالَ by first narrator
potential_issues.impact: The opening term قَالَ by Abdah ibn Abdullah may indicate indirect transmission or reporting rather than direct narration.

Topics: Advice on remembrance of death and preparation
Incident of specific counsel to Tariq by the Prophet ﷺ

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sufyan al-Muharibi (from his father, from his grandfather): The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Stop your people from drinking wine from jars, for it is forbidden by Allah the Mighty and Majestic, and His Messenger ﷺ'

narrators.name: Ruh ibn Jamil Abu Muhammad al-Qurri
Yazid ibn Fudayl
narrators.full_name: Yazid ibn Fudayl ibn Amr ibn Sufyan al-Muharibi

narrators.name: His father (Fudayl ibn Amr)
narrators.full_name: Fudayl ibn Amr ibn Sufyan al-Muharibi

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: The chain goes through father and grandfather of the main narrator, creating a familial transmission
Both the father and grandfather use عَنْ in this chain

potential_issues.impact: The hadith is transmitted through Yazid ibn Fudayl from his father Fudayl, from his grandfather Sufyan. While these are reliable narrators, familial transmission chains sometimes require additional scrutiny. However, the reliability grades of these narrators (all Saduq or Thiqah) mitigate this concern.

Topics: Prohibition of drinking wine from jars (nabidh)
Command to stop people from drinking fermented wine

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Amru ibn Absah: If it were not for the saying of Abu Najih al-Sulami, I would have devoted my wealth to the way of Allah, then I would have gone to a valley from the valleys of Lebanon and worshipped Allah there due to what I see of deficiency

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Amru ibn Absah (May Allah be pleased with him): I came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and gave him my pledge of allegiance for Islam. Amru said: I saw myself as the fourth Muslim

narrators.name: al-Walid ibn Muslim
narrators.full_name: al-Walid ibn Muslim ibn al-Mughirah al-Uqayli

chainIssues: Use of أَنَّ construction may indicate indirect transmission

potential_issues.impact: May indicate indirect or reported hearing rather than direct narration

Topics: Incident of Amru ibn Absah accepting Islam as the fourth Muslim

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated that Abu Umamah asked Amru ibn Absah: By what do you claim that you were the fourth Muslim? He replied: I came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ in Makkah and said: Who has followed you in this matter? He said: A free man and a slave, and with him are Bilal and Abu Bakr (May Allah be pleased with them)
Topics: Incident of Amru ibn Absah's early conversion and fourth person to accept Islam
Dialogue between Abu Umamah and Amru ibn Absah
Names of early Muslims: Abu Bakr and Bilal

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Amru ibn Absah: Whoever builds a mosque for Allah the Mighty and Majestic wherein Allah is remembered, builds for him a house in Paradise. And whoever frees a Muslim soul, it becomes his ransom from Hellfire. And whoever turns grey in Islam, it becomes for him a light on the Day of Resurrection

chainIssues: Khalid ibn Muaddan is from generation 7 but appears late in chain

potential_issues.impact: Uses of عَنْ introduce ambiguity but narrators are all Saduq or better

Topics: Freeing slaves and ransom from Hellfire
Greying in Islam and light on the Day of Judgment

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Amru ibn Absah: I was cast (thrown) into knowledge...

potential_issues.impact: Uses indirect construction but narrators are all reliable

Topics: Incident of Amru ibn Absah and knowledge of Islam
